spans.content: All-Inorganic Glass Scintillators: Scintillation Mechanism, Materials, and Applications
Jiaqi Liu, Xudong Zhao, Yinsheng Xu,\* Haodi Wu, Xuhui Xu, Ping Lu, Xianghua Zhang, Xiujian Zhao, Mengling Xia,\* Jiang Tang, and Guangda Niu\*

Glass scintillators have several benefits compared to the currently used single or polycrystalline scintillators, including non-hygroscopicity, mechanical ruggedness, ease of producing customizable shapes, and low-cost synthesis. The combination of the inert glass matrix and the embedded highly scintillating center render them significant materials for medical imaging and therapy, non-destructive probing, nuclear monitoring, and high-energy physics. Recently, great progress has been made in exploring new kinds of glass scintillator materials, improving imaging resolution for radiation detection, and developing an enormous range of commercial products. However, the majority of efforts have been devoted to the variation of materials, while rationally designing this new family of scintillators toward expected properties and applications is still lacking. In this review, the focus is specifically on advances in glass scintillators, including the scintillation fundamentals, material designing rule, and current application status, as well as future challenges and future directions.

The primary criteria for scintillators include excellent attenuation of high-energy photons or particles, high light yield, enduring physical and chemical stability, as well as radiation resistance.[10-13] Typical inorganic scintillators are usually in the form of single crystals, polycrystalline ceramics, and amorphous glasses composed of luminescent activator and non-luminescent matrix. Conventional activator-doped single crystals scintillators, such as thallium-activated CsI:Tl, exhibit high light yield, good timing and energy resolutions. glass scintillators for neutron detection,[44] to our best knowledge, no systematic overview has been made for all-inorganic glass scintillators until now. A deep understanding of the scintillation mechanism, and material design and application of different types of glass scintillators is necessary. We can expect that these materials will show powerful

performance and application prospects in radiation detection fields, which can promote the in-depth study of high-energy radiation physics and the development of a new generation of radiation detection instruments. Here, we give a comprehensive review over the scintillation fundamentals, materials and preparation, scintillation performance, and corresponding applications of glass scintillators. We first summarize the scintillation fundamentals for different categories, including the rare earth activated, nanocrystals activated and radioisotope activated, then discuss the preparation methods and research status of these glass scintillators, and then review the scintillation performance of glass scintillators and application explorations of
-ray and thermal neutron detection and optical fiber plates. Last, we propose research directions to overcome the major challenges associated with these glasses for ultimate applications.

. In accordance with the parity selection rules, also referred to as Judd-Ofelt theory,[62] electric dipole transition is only feasible between different parity states. Therefore, f-d transition is permissible while f-f transition is always forbidden. Nevertheless, if the surrounding crystal field has no center of symmetry, f-f transition can be allowed to generate a narrow emission band with a long decay time. The permissible f-d transition, such as 5d-4f transition in

As shown in Figure 3d, due to the large bandgap of glass matrix (or the micro/nano crystals in glass), the orbit energy levels of rare earth ions are within the band gap and generate luminescent centers. If the energy level of the excited state of rare earth ions is lower than the conduction band minimum of glass matrix (or the micro/nano crystals in glass), or the ground state of rare earth ions is higher than the valence band maximum of glass matrix (or the micro/nano crystals in glass), the electrons and holes rapidly transfer to the excited state level and ground state level of the rare earth ions, respectively. In the subsequent deexcitation process, the excited electrons return back to the ground state accompanying the scintillating emission. The remaining electron-hole pairs are consumed by thermal radiation through electron-phonon coupling.[33,65-68] The performance of rare earth ions doped glass scintillators strongly hinges on the density and phonon energy of the glass or nanocrystals in glass.

Nanocrystals have attracted considerable attention due to their unique optical and electronic properties compared to their bulk counterparts.[69,70] Chemically synthesized nanocrystals have demonstrated exceptional luminescent properties, including high photoluminescence quantum yield

and short emission lifetime (approximately nanoseconds), making them ideal candidates for scintillator applications. Furthermore, nanocrystals activated glass scintillators effectively mitigate the problem of nanocrystals agglomeration in solution and provide exceptional optical properties without compromising stability.
As illustrated in Figure 3e, when X-rays are incident on nanocrystals activated glass scintillator, the energy is absorbed

and subsequently transferred to the nanocrystals. The ensuing high-energy electrons and holes generated are rapidly thermally relaxed into the band edges of conduction and valence, respectively. Visible emission is generated by the recombination of electrons and holes at the edges of the conduction and valence bands of nanocrystals. Unlike the fixed orbital transitions of rare earths, the luminescence color of nanocrystals activated glasses can be controlled by tuning the band gap energy.[2,71,72] The scintillation process observed in nanocrystals activated glass scintillator is primarily governed by the presence of highly emissive triplet excited states, which are unique characteristics of nanocrystals, along with a large absorption cross-section and fast emission output.[73,74]

Endeavorshave been made to investigate and develop novel glass scintillators due to their distinct advantages. To satisfy the requirements for a good material for glass scintillator, the following goals for different applications are constantly being pursued:
i. High density. The high density of glass scintillator ensures their ability to absorb high-energy rays or particles.[75]
ii. High light yield. Strong scintillation light output can reduce statistical fluctuation and improve detection accuracy and spatial resolution.[76]
iii. Low detection limit. A low detection limit can reduce radiation doses, which is essential, especially in human medical diagnostics.[77]
iv. Short decay time. The decay time of glass scintillator determines the response rate to the incident

-ray and neutrons. Glass scintillation materials with short decay time can reduce the signal deposition caused by energy accumulation, avoid the overlapping of two adjacent event images, and improve the temporal resolution.[21]

v. Low afterglow effect. In high-speed radiography applications, low afterglow of glass scintillators is required to avoid blurring of high-speed X-ray imaging, such as the ghost generated by X-ray CT, and increase the image contrast.[78,79]

After exposure to large doses of radiation, the chemical bond of glass scintillators may be damaged, forming color centers in the matrix, thus deteriorating the scintillation performance. High radiation resistance of glass scintillators is necessary for long-time use.[81,82]

The chemical bonds of the compound are broken and rebonded through high temperature co-melting and rapid quenching of the raw materials mentioned above, and a short-range ordered and long-range disordered glass network structure is finally formed. If the activator is nanocrystals, after the rapid quenching and molding of the glass melt, the "dissociative state" ions that make up nanocrystals will be re-bonded through the subsequent heat treatment to make nanocrystals precipitate in the glass.

The process of preparing the glass scintillator is depicted in Figure 4. First, the raw materials matching the glass composition are mixed and thoroughly ground. They are then melted at high temperature to form glass melt, with the melting temperature and time varying according to the glass composition. The melt is quickly poured into a mold for quenching to form solid glass. The as-quenched glass is then annealed at a temperature lower than the glass transition temperature to release the mechanical stress, and the glass scintillator without nanocrystals is obtained. If nanocrystals are needed to form in glass, the as-annealed glass should be further heat-treated at the crystallization temperature. The precipitation of nanocrystals in glass initiates by the diffusion-controlled phase separation in glass. The

crystallization of glass is completed in two steps: the first is to form crystal nucleus in the glass and the second is the growing up of the crystal nucleus. The heat-treatment temperature across the nucleation energy barrier is the key factor in the process of nanocrystals formation in glass. Nanocrystals with desired size in glass can be obtained by controlling heat-treatment temperature and duration. According to different activators, glass scintillators can be divided into three categories: rare earth activated, nanocrystal activated, and radioactive isotopes activated.

In conclusion, major advances have been made recently in glass scintillators, including exploring new materials (such as perovskite composite glass scintillators), uncovering new mechanisms (such as damage-recovery scintillation) and expanding new applications (such as X-ray imaging and neutron imaging). With the characteristics of tunable composition, good uniformity, isotropy, good light transmittance, stable physical and chemical properties, and easy preparation and processing into various shapes, Li-glass scintillators have already achieved large-scale industrial production and new glass scintillators show promise for even wider applications. In order to meet the growing demands of various radiation detection applications, including radiation protection, cosmic ray detection, monitoring of special nuclear materials, medical diagnostic technology, high energy physics or nuclear physics research, space physics research, industrial and geological exploration, additional research is needed to improve glass scintillators in several areas. These areas include, but are not limited to, the following subsections.
5.1. Deep Understanding of the Topological Structure of Multicomponent Glass Scintillators

The network structure of glass directly determines the key factors of glass scintillator: i) glass density, which dominates the absorption ability of high-energy photons; ii) tolerance and interaction to the luminescent center, which affects the energy deposition and transfer; iii) glass transmittance, which affects the light output efficiency; and iv) stability. A deep understanding of the topological structure of multicomponent glass scintillators is beneficial to rationally increase the proportion of heavy atoms, such as Cs, Ba, Ta, W, Bi, etc., dope luminescent center ideally into an optimized glass matrix and obtain the best performance. However, the theory of the glass network has been controversial for several decades of research. Furthermore, since the multicomponent glass matrix is a much more complicated system of amorphous and nonconductivity, the internal environment for luminescent centers is difficult to be characterized by routine means. Theoretical calculation is a good way to understand the glass topological structure. For example, the cross-scale characterization of

the glass microstructure and chemical composition was realized by utilizing Born-Mayer function.[119] More models of glass topological structure based on calculation should be established for further unfolding the network of glass scintillators.
5.2. Exploring New Activators for Glass Scintillators

Taking advantage of the high protection and compatibility of amorphous glass to luminescent ions and nanocrystals, more luminescent centers could be explored to extend the materials category. Although Cd chalcogenide and Pb-halide perovskite nanocrystals embedded glasses have been considered as hopeful scintillator materials, they are still unsuitable for large-scale application due to the toxicity of Pb and Cd elements. To solve this problem, Bi-, Sn-, and Sb-based perovskite nanocrystals embedded in glasses may be considered as alternatives. Highly luminescent clusters or radicals involving radioactive isotopes, such as
